summary.p: Gast has so far been unable to write any verified news about [Duke Heinrich of] Brunswick, as the Papists spread the rumor that [Landgrave Philipp of Hesse] had been completely destroyed with his entire army. But God does not abandon His own: Now the Papists mourn [Heinrich's] capture. Bullinger should return the enclosed document. Certainly, [regarding Heinrich's capture] a letter has already been sent to the [Zurich] council. - [Sebastian von Heusenstamm] has been elected as the Archbishop of Mainz. It is said that he is from Eisenach. He neither comes from a significant family nor is he well-connected. Consequently, there is not much to fear from him. - The Bishop of Trier [Johann IV Ludwig von Hagen] is said to be seriously ill and, according to other rumors, already dead. - Bullinger has probably heard about the 20,000 confiscated arquebuses in Kempten. Someone [...] wrote to Gast that for [Landgrave Philipp of] Hesse, the victory [over Heinrich] was easy. It is said that no more than 400 [men] fell on both sides.

div.p: S. So far, I have been unable to write anything certain about the Duke of Brunswick due to the uncertain rumors spread by the Papists. They boasted that [Landgrave Philipp of] Hesse was completely destroyed with his entire army; but it was seen quite differently by the Lord, who never abandons His own.

The plans they have been working on for many years are now becoming evident. The Papists walk with a sad face since their redeemer has been captured. Read the enclosed document and return it. However, I believe that the essence of this matter has already been written to your council.

Furthermore, I do not want to hide from you that a noble and learned man has been elected as the Archbishop of Mainz. They say he is from Eisenach. He is not from a significant family, nor does he have a large following (supporters, entourage), and thus there is less danger to be feared from him. There is also a persistent rumor that the Bishop of Trier is seriously ill; some assert that he is dead, but these are of uncertain credibility.

You know about the 20,000 confiscated arquebuses in Kempten. Furthermore, someone wrote to me that this victory was very convenient for [Landgrave Philipp of] Hesse. It is thought that no more than 400 men fell on both sides.
Farewell in the Lord and be safe. November 2, 1545. Yours, Gastius.
To the well-learned gentleman, Mr. Heinrich Bullinger, pastor in Zurich, my dear, gracious lord and friend.
